official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a database that shall serve as a central
			 location for information from investigations relating to human trafficking
			 for Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Coordinated Assistance To Catch Human Traffickers Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Coordinated Assistance To Catch Human Traffickers Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The scourge of human trafficking persists and manifests itself in the modern era, whether termed
			 modern-day slavery, forced labor, involuntary domestic servitude, sex
			 trafficking, child sex trafficking, bonded labor, forced child labor, or
			 debt bondage among migrant laborers.

According to the 2013 Trafficking in Persons (TIP) Report of the United States Department of State,
			 each year an estimated 14,500 to 17,500 foreign nationals are trafficked
			 into the United States, with the largest number of people trafficked into
			 the United States coming from East Asia and the Pacific, and the next
			 highest numbers coming from Latin America, Europe, and Eurasia.

The majority of victims of modern-day slavery are women and children because traffickers prey on
			 those who suffer most from gender discrimination, family violence, and a
			 lack of access to education and economic opportunity.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, ranking with drug smuggling and
			 arms dealing in organized crime activities.

text.#text:
Human trafficking is one of the fastest growing criminal enterprises in the 21st century,
			 generating profits for traffickers in excess of $30,000,000,000, according
			 to the

There remains a stark disparity between the large global problem of trafficking in persons and the
			 low numbers of prosecutions and convictions of forced labor trafficking
			 crimes, which accounted for less than 3 percent of all convictions
			 worldwide as recently as 2009.

text.#text:
The head of a Federal, State, or local law enforcement agency conducting an investigation related
			 to human trafficking shall ensure that such information relating to that
			 investigation as the

shall reduce the amount that would otherwise be awarded
			 to that State or unit of local government under such grant program by 20
			 percent.
